content.webTitle: A Midsummer Night's Dream review – RSC's delightful ‘play for the nation’

fields.headline: A Midsummer Night's Dream review – RSC's delightful ‘play for the nation’
fields.bodyText: Past and present, reality and the domain of theatre and the imagination go cheek by jowl in Erica Whyman’s delightful Dream. It comes dusted with magic, glee and a sense that we can dream a better world. There are two lovely moments towards the end: in one, the tension between Ayesha Dharker’s sexy Titania and Chu Omambala’s brooding, regretful Oberon dissipates and they are reconciled with tenderness; in the other, the fairy children – dressed like returning second world war evacuees – stare across the auditorium as if glimpsing their own futures. Omambala’s Oberon has real depth – he is an apparently cool cat in a sleek white suit but with melancholic undertones, and his relationship with Puck has an erotic undertow. The production will tour the country, at each location featuring actors from a local amateur group to play Shakespeare’s rude mechanicals – the artisan performers who are rehearsing the entirely inappropriate tragedy of Pyramus and Thisbe to celebrate the nuptials of Theseus and Hippolyta. At the performance I saw they were played by members of Wyre Forest’s Nonentities Society, who set about disproving their company’s name with distinctiveness, gusto and real craft. The play within a play is blissfully funny, which isn’t always the case. Chris Clarke’s excellent Bottom dies with all the ridiculous flourish of the amateur actor enjoying his moment in the limelight. The tour and the community element earn this revival its add-on subtitle “a play for the nation”. But other meanings are delivered via Tom Piper’s design that offers a bombed-out theatre and 1940s costumes, and a production that in its portrayal of women hints that the attitudes of the past are being swept away by a new order, leaving masculinity in crisis. Theseus is made uncomfortable by Hippolyta, Helena’s RAF hero father finds himself out of step with new thinking, and Quince, played by Sue Downing, is a woman trying to take control as a director. The dust left by bombs is replaced by the vivid colours of the Hindu festival Holi, the sound of destruction by the jazzy beat of a new era as spring arrives in a shower of rose petals. Around it all skips Lucy Ellinson’s delicious, androgynous Puck – part overenthusiastic artful dodger, part cross-dressing music-hall male impersonator – an impish ghost whose eyes pop with sheer wonder at this new world. • At Royal Shakespeare theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon, until 5 March, then 17 May to 16 July. To buy tickets, go to Guardian box office. On tour 16 March to 4 June.
